raw_text:
EU 'too slow' on economic reforms
 
 Most EU countries have failed to put in place policies aimed at making Europe the world's most competitive economy by the end of the decade, a report says.
 
 The study, undertaken by the European Commission, sought to assess how far the EU has moved towards meeting its economic targets. In 2000, EU leaders at a summit in Lisbon pledged the European economy would outstrip that of the US by 2010. Their economic targets became known as the Lisbon Agenda. But the Commission report says that, in most EU countries, the pace of economic reform has been too slow, and fulfilling the Lisbon ambitions will be difficult - if not impossible.
 
 Only the UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland and the Netherlands have actually followed up policy recommendations. Among the biggest laggards, according to the report, are Greece and Italy. The Lisbon Agenda set out to increase the number of people employed in Europe by encouraging more older people and women to stay in the workforce. It also set out to raise the amount the private sector spends on research and development, while bringing about greater discipline over public spending and debt levels. Combined with high environmental standards and efforts to level the playing field for businesses throughout the EU, the plan was for Europe to become the world's most dynamic economy by 2010. Next week, the Commission will present revised proposals to meet the Lisbon goals. Many people expect the 2010 target to be quietly dropped.
llama3.2:1b: Most EU countries have failed to implement economic reforms aimed at making Europe competitive.
The European Commission report found that the pace of reform has been too slow in most countries and fulfilling the Lisbon ambitions will be difficult.
Greece and Italy are among the biggest laggards, with only a few countries, including the UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the Netherlands following up policy recommendations.
llama3.2:3b: EU countries have failed to implement economic reforms aimed at making Europe the world's most competitive economy by 2010, a report by the European Commission says.
Only six countries have followed policy recommendations, with Greece and Italy among the biggest laggards.
The Lisbon Agenda set out to increase workforce participation, boost research and development, and reduce public debt, but many experts expect the 2010 target to be dropped.
gemma2:2b: EU countries have failed to implement economic reforms necessary for becoming a world-leading competitive economy by the end of the decade.
The EU's 2000 "Lisbon Agenda" aimed to surpass US economic strength and achieve this goal, but many countries are lagging behind in implementing necessary policies.
Only a few EU nations have followed recommendations, while others like Greece and Italy fall behind.

The Lisbon Agenda focused on workforce participation, private sector R&D spending, public spending control, environmental standards, and business competition within the EU to boost European economic growth.
The original 2010 target is likely to be abandoned.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The European Union is too slow in implementing economic reforms to meet its ambitious goals of becoming the world's most competitive economy by 2010.

The report suggests that only a few EU countries have moved forward with their economic policies, while other countries lag behind due to issues like high levels of unemployment and insufficient public spending.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The European Union has failed to achieve its economic reform targets set in 2000, and it is unlikely to reach the Lisbon Agenda's ambitious goal of making Europe the world's most competitive economy by 2010.
Only a few countries have implemented policy recommendations, while Greece and Italy are major laggards.
The EU plans for more employed people, increased private sector R&D spending, disciplined public finances, and environmental standards to make Europe dynamic.
qwen2.5:3b: EU 'too slow' on economic reforms: Most EU countries have failed to implement policies aimed at making Europe the world's most competitive economy by 2010, despite initial pledges in the Lisbon Agenda.
Only a few member states like UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland and the Netherlands followed recommendations.
Greece and Italy are major laggards.

The agenda aimed to boost employment, R&D spending, fiscal discipline, environmental standards and business equality by 2010, but many EU countries have not met these targets, prompting revised proposals for meeting Lisbon goals, with some expecting a shift in emphasizing 2010 target.
opencoder:1.5b: The European Union (EU) report on 'too slow' economic reform in the last decade highlights countries that are still struggling with reaching their stated economic targets.
Despite attempts by many leaders, the pace of reform is not always swift.

While countries like the UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and Netherlands have shown consistent progress in addressing these issues, some of them might face similar challenges once the goals are achieved.

However, the Commission's revised proposals, aimed at increasing employment, raising funds for research and development, increased public spending and discipline prevention, leveling the playing field among businesses and environmental regulations could potentially make Europe more competitive by 2020.
smollm:1.7b: The EU has failed to put in place policies aimed at making Europe the world's most competitive economy by the end of the decade, according to a report.
The study assesses how far the EU has moved towards meeting its economic targets set out in 2000.
In 2000, EU leaders promised to make Europe the world's most competitive economy by 2010.
Their economic targets became known as the Lisbon Agenda.
But the Commission report says that, in most EU countries, the pace of economic reform has been too slow and fulfilling the Lisbon ambitions will be difficult - if not impossible.
The biggest laggards among the EU member states are Greece and Italy, according to the report.
These two countries have failed to follow up policy recommendations set out by the European Commission in 2000.
The report cites other major laggards as well, including Germany, France, Spain and the Netherlands.
The report suggests that the EU has not made sufficient progress towards meeting its economic targets.
It notes that many countries have failed to increase the number of people employed in Europe by encouraging more older people and women to stay in the workforce.
The report also highlights a lack of discipline over public spending and debt levels, which are among the highest in the EU.
The European Commission has proposed revised proposals to meet the Lisbon goals, but many people expect the 2010 target to be quietly dropped.
The report suggests that the pace of economic reform will need to increase significantly if the EU is to achieve its ambitious targets.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The EU's economic reforms face significant challenges as they set a target for Europe to compete globally by 2010.
While some countries have taken steps toward implementing policy recommendations, others remain lagging behind.
The report highlights progress in increasing employment and private sector investments but notes that achieving these goals remains difficult due to slower reform efforts.
Only specific EU members, including Greece and Italy, have implemented recommended reforms.
The Lisbon Agenda aims to enhance employments across Europe while boosting private sector research and development.
Environmental standards are also emphasized to level the playing field for businesses.
The Commission is considering revised proposals next week, with hopes of meeting the 2010 target quietly.
tinyllama:1.1b: The EU has failed to keep pace with the US in terms of becoming the most competitive economy by the end of the decade, according to a report from the European Commission.

While the Lisbon Agenda set out to increase employment rates and encourage more women and older people to stay in the workforce, the Commission found that only three EU countries have implemented policies aimed at meeting economic targets.
The UK has followed up recommendations, while Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the Netherlands are lagging behind.
The Commission's proposals for next week will address environmental standards and business competition to keep Europe competitive in the face of falling global growth.
Despite this lack of progress, some experts expect the 2010 target to be quietly dropped.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The European Union is facing backlash for its perceived slow pace of economic reform.
According to a recent report by the European Commission, most EU countries have failed to effectively address their economic targets and strive for a competitive and prosperous Europe.
The study analyzed how well the EU has been meeting its ambitious economic goals from 2000, pledged at the Lisbon summit in Portugal.
Despite this, only three countries - Greece, Italy, and Greece - have fully implemented their recommendations.
In contrast, some countries are lagging behind, such as the UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the Netherlands.
These nations need to improve if they hope to meet the 2010 goals set by the Lisbon Agenda.
phi:2.7b: The European Union (EU) has struggled to implement policies that make it more competitive globally, as its economic targets set in 2010 have not been met.
Only a few countries like UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland and the Netherlands have followed through on policy recommendations, while others like Greece and Italy have lagged behind.
The report suggests that fulfilling the Lisbon goals will be difficult if not impossible without more reform efforts.
The report was conducted by the European Commission in 2020 to assess progress towards meeting the EU's economic targets.
orca-mini:3b: The European Union has failed to put in place policies aimed at making Europe the world's most competitive economy by the end of the decade as most EU countries have been too slow with their economic reforms, according to a Commission report.
The report found that only the UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the Netherlands have actually followed up policy recommendations.
Greece and Italy are among the biggest laggards, according to the report.

The Lisbon Agenda aimed to increase the number of people employed in Europe by encouraging more older people and women to stay in the workforce, while also raising the amount the private sector spends on research and development, while bringing about greater discipline over public spending and debt levels.
However, the plan was for Europe to become the world's most dynamic economy by 2010.
hermes3:3b: EU countries slow on economic reforms, lagging Lisbon Agenda targets.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The European Union (EU) has failed to implement policies for making it the world's most competitive economy by 2010, according to a report by the European Commission.

Only six out of 27 EU countries have fulfilled policy recommendations from the Lisbon Agenda, which aimed to increase employment, boost research and development spending in the private sector, and enforce discipline on public spending and debt levels.
The original target of surpassing the US economy by 2010 seems unlikely to be met.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Most EU countries have been too slow in implementing economic reforms needed to achieve the Lisbon Agenda's goal of making Europe the world's most competitive economy by 2010, according to a European Commission report.
While the UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the Netherlands have followed policy recommendations, countries like Greece and Italy have lagged behind.
The agenda aimed to boost employment, increase private sector research investment, and enforce fiscal discipline while maintaining high environmental standards.
With progress insufficient, the Commission is set to present revised proposals, and many expect the 2010 target to be abandoned.
stablelm2:1.6b: The European Union has failed to achieve its goal of becoming the most competitive economy by the end of the decade, according to a report from the European Commission.
The study assesses the progress made towards meeting economic targets set out by EU leaders in Lisbon.

Most countries have not put in place policies to make Europe more competitive; however, only the UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the Netherlands have followed through on policy recommendations.
Greece and Italy are among the biggest laggards.

The plan included encouraging more women and older people to stay in the workforce, increasing employment rates, boosting research and development spending by the private sector, and improving public spending discipline and environmental standards.
Many experts expect the goal of reaching the target to be dropped.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The European Union (EU) has fallen short of its 2010 economic targets outlined in the Lisbon Agenda, according to a report by the European Commission.

This agenda aimed to make Europe's economy surpass that of the US, increase employment through older and female labor force participation, boost private sector R&D spending, and enhance public fiscal discipline.
However, most EU countries have not implemented sufficient reforms; key laggards include Greece and Italy.
The UK, Finland, Belgium, Denmark, Ireland, and the Netherlands are the exceptions.
The revised proposals, expected next week from the Commission, may downgrade or abandon the 2010 target due to this slow progress.
